data: Exploring the teaching of Citizenship, children's rights and sustainable development in Finnish Education

Caversham Primary School is a large primary school in Reading which was rated 'Outstanding' by OFSTED during its last inspection. Caversham have recently been awarded Rights Respecting Schools Award Level 2 and full accreditation of the International Schools Award. The school bases its teaching and learning around the 5 'Core Values': Determination, Enthusiasm, Cooperation, Respect and Compassion; with children's rights being of paramount importance. As part of school improvement, Caversham identified the need to develop the European dimension in the school with the aims of: enhancing the teaching and learning of citizenship across the school; empowering children to become active citizens and learners and providing opportunities to learn about sustainable development through the UN Global Goals.

The broad objectives of the project are:

*To understand how citizenship is taught in other countries across Europe and how this links into other curriculum areas
*To work collaboratively with our partner school on joint projects in relation to citizenship, environment (sustainability) and children's rights.

In 2016 we used etwinning to find a school with similar interests and we successfully developed a partnership with Nuolialan koulu in Pirkkala, Finland. The school is a large school made up of pre-school and primary (grades 1- 6) and is expanding to include secondary school pupils (grades 7-9). The school is involved in a sustainability project and, as part of the introduction of a new Finnish curriculum, has a particular interest in global citizenship.

After an introductory project sharing information about both schools, Nuolialan koulu applied for KA1 funding to visit us to understand our teaching of citizenship and with a particular focus on provision for children with SEN. Two teachers came to  Caversham in November 2016 and undertook job-showing activities and interviews with subject coordinators.

Both schools have continued to work together and, in order to meet Caversham Primary's development needs, have planned for teachers from Caversham to visit Finland to better understand the teaching of citizenship in other countries and to benefit from learning about Nuolialan koulu's sustainability project. Two teachers from Caversham will travel to Finland and participate in a week of timetabled observations, interviews and joint planning time in order to plan a detailed project of continued cooperation between the two schools. They will gather information, keep records of observations, report back to all stakeholders and communicate their visit through a blog on the school Virtual Learning Environment.

The outcomes of the project will be such that Caversham can: compare citizenship teaching between countries and use this learning to enhance the teaching and learning in our school; plan collaborative projects with a focus on citizenship and sustainability; empower pupils to work in partnership with Finnish pupils to promote positive change in the world; and develop a scheme of work/series of lessons across the school so that the whole school community will benefit from the partnership working.

This work will be shared with governors, at subject coordinator network meetings and through a series of dedicated staff training time in order to have maximum impact on staff and pupils. The wider teaching community will also benefit from the work undertaken.

The project will be evaluated thoroughly and further opportunities for continued collaboration identified.
Taking Nanotechnological Remediation Processes from Lab Scale to End User Applications for the Restoration of a Clean Environment

NANOREM is designed to unlock the potential of nanoremediation and so support both the appropriate use of nanotechnology in restoring land and aquifer resources and the development of the knowledge-based economy at a world leading level for the benefit of a wide range of users in the EU environmental sector.
NANOREM uniquely takes a holistic approach to examining how the potential for nanoremediation can be developed and applied in practice, to enhance a stronger development of nanoremediation markets and applications in the EU. NANOREM’s ambitious objectives are:
1) Identification of the most appropriate nanoremediation technological approaches to achieve a step change in practical remediation performance. Development of lower cost production techniques and production at commercially relevant scales, also for large scale applications. 2) Determination of the mobility and migration potential of nanoparticles in the subsurface, and their potential to cause harm, focusing on the NP types most likely to be adopted into practical use in the EU.
3) Development of a comprehensive tool box for field scale observation of nanoremediation performance and determination of the fate of NPs in the subsurface, including analytical methods, field measurement devices, decision support and numerical tools.
4) Dissemination and dialogue with key stakeholder interests to ensure that research, development and demonstration meets end-user and regulatory requirements and information and knowledge is shared widely across the EU.
5) Provide applications at representative scales including field sites to validate cost, performance, and fate and transport findings.
The NANOREM consortium is multidisciplinary, cross-sectoral and transnational. It includes 28 partners from 12 countries organized in 11 work packages. The consortium includes 18 of the leading nanoremediation research groups in the EU, 10 industry and service providers (8 SMEs) and one organisation with policy and regulatory interest.

HOMBRE seeks to achieve a paradigm shift in sustainable brownfield land management practice. This strategic goal can be expressed in four underlying objectives:
•	Better understanding why, how, where and when brownfields are formed in order to avoid future brownfields.
•	Better solutions for long term land use of current and potential future brownfields.
•	Better operations, better implementation of state of the art technologies into practice and development of more sustainable integrated regeneration technologies for successful brownfield regeneration
•	Improving the dividend from brownfield remediation for the environment, economy and society in the surrounding area by means of integrative management methodologies in cooperation with stakeholders

The project recognizes four different main tasks as part of a HOlistic Management of Brownfield REgeneration (HOMBRE) to be accomplished in associated case studies (mining, urban, industrial) with stakeholder participation:
•	Zero brownfields strategy: a better understanding of the life cycle of urban, industrial and mining sites and the origination of brownfields in these settings is necessary to device a successful overall brownfield redevelopment program.
•	Assessment of brownfield regeneration scenarios: development of an improved sustainable spatial (land-, urban) planning and decision making processes to enhance the up-take of brownfield regeneration projects based on a holistic approach.
•	Integrated Regeneration Technologies:  combination of technologies that address different site aspects or issues (eg. linking soil, water, energy and materials) to create faster and cheaper solutions during brownfield regeneration.
•	Intermediate Renewal: solutions for greening, landscaping and amenity improvement of brownfields to ensure social, economical and environmental cohesion with the surrounding land use.
Support to Regulatory Activities for Carbon Capture and Storage

STRACO2 will support the ongoing development of a comprehensive regulatory framework in the European Union for CO2 capture and storage technologies (CCS) for zero emission applications. This will respond to the requirements of multi-stakeholder groups in Europe affected by these technologies and their applications both domestically in Europe and under future inclusion in emissions trading schemes and Kyoto mechanisms.  Through a focus on the regulatory aspects of international trade and technology transfer structures, the EU regulatory framework will then form the basis for dialogue and priority setting with regulatory authorities in China. In this regard local priorities, the ongoing EU-China cooperation in CCS and the need for establishing an international gateway for CCS adoption and the trade implications will be key underlying themes.

Wspieranie zdobywania umiejętności i kompetencji przez uczniów z niepełnosprawnością intelektualną
Rozwój kompetencji kadry Chrześcijańskiej Szkoły Podstawowej im. Króla Dawida w zakresie pomocy pedagogiczno-psychologicznej, metodyki oraz mentoringu uczniów

Zwiększenie specjalistycznych kompetencji nauczycieli w zakresie prowadzenia edukacji włączającej, przeciwdziałania wykluczeniu i działań rewalidacyjnych oraz międzynarodowa wymiana doświadczeń szansą na sukces uczniów z niepełnosprawnościami

The two years long project „ Increasing specialist competences of teachers in inclusive education,  rehabilitation and preventing social exclusion and international exchange of experiences in those fields as a chance for  pupils with disabilities to achieve success” is a  response to the needs defined in the framework of European School Development Plan.
The main aims of the Project are:
I. Increasing teachers’ competences in:
1) conducting inclusive education and preventing social exclusion of students with visual impairments or disabilities, hearing disabilities, cerebral palsy, cognitive disabilities, autism, Asperger Syndrome  and physical disabilities. 
2) Using  ICT in special needs education and inclusive education of students with visual impairments or disabilities, hearing disabilities, cerebral palsy, cognitive disabilities, autism, Asperger Syndrome  and physical disabilities. 
II. Increasing the quality of education thanks to implementing good practices in inclusive education and preventing social exclusion of students with disabilities as well as using ITC in special needs education.
The participates of the projects are teachers, educational specialists, psychologist, speech therapist and other specialists working at our school, who will take part in 32 mobilities. The main project activities are: participation in trainings and job shadowing in  order to increase skills and knowledge in specialist fields inclusive and special needs education. We assume that the knowledge and skills learnt during the project will be shared with remaining work colleagues and other specialist working in the local area.
The Project Management Cycle will be used to effectively plan, conduct and evaluate the Project. The results of the project will be visible after the aims listed above are met. One of them will be the increase in the quality of work of specialists in education, therapy and rehabilitation at our institution.
Impact of the Project will be visible in a short and in a long run. The project will bring an increase of satisfaction of its participants as well as school’s clients: both pupils and their parents.  It will be done thanks to specialist methods of inclusive education and prevention of social exclusion as well as by using ICT methods in special needs education. 
The potential long term results will be visible not only within the institution itself but also in the surrounding area of our school. It will be done thanks to undertaking activities aimed at greater integration with local environment as well as thanks to promoting the results of the project.
